title: A lot of Teslas just became semi-autonomous overnight - News and reviews
text:
New Autopilot features are demonstrated in a Tesla Model S. REUTERS Overnight, tens of thousands of Tesla drivers became semi-autonomous car owners thanks to an over-the-air system update that took place October 14.
Related Links What you need to know before driving in the snow this winter Mercedes-Benz made a bunch of kids miserable with toy cars that won’t crash People abandon their cars at Logan Airport and now they are up for auction According to Wired , over the course of a week, the update will affect every Tesla made and sold in the U.S. in the past year, letting cars drive themselves using various sensors, cameras, fleet data, and radar technology. The update marks a major step toward the self-driving future that seems inevitable, and puts Tesla way out in front of a crowd of carmakers pursuing their own autonomous systems.
But that doesn’t mean drivers can take a nap in the back seat.
Due to different driving regulations all over the country, Tesla is still having drivers keep their hands on the steering wheel, even in “Autopilot” mode. (If you move your hand away, a message will ask you to touch the wheel after a few seconds.)
But the new Autopilot mode does include “Autosteer,” which uses real-time feedback features, sensors, and 360-degree ultrasonic sonar to track lanes and watch out for other vehicles. This allows the car to steer and maintain a safe speed. Another feature, “Auto Lane Change,” makes sure there isn’t any obstacle in the way before switching lanes. The driver just has to put on the proper turn signal and check for blind spots.
Story continues after gallery.
New and improved cars for 2016:
 Some cars are going to be very different in 2016. A few popular brands, including the Honda Civic and the Toyota Prius, will be getting upgrades like better engines and improved range. Another car will run on hydrogen, while others like, the all-electric Tesla Model X (pictured) will offer a very unique design. Check out the cars to look forward to driving in 2016. Tesla 2016 Honda Civic. As Consumer Reports tells it, consumers were so dissatisfied with the current version of the Civic that Honda pushed a replacement version six months earlier than anticipated. When it arrives in the fall of 2015, the redesigned Honda Civic will have a base 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine. A 1.5-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder will also be available. Honda also says the cabin will be quieter, more refined, and offer more room. Don Emmert / AFP / Getty Images 2016 Volvo XC90. After more than a decade, Volvo finally gave the XC90 – first introduced in 2002 – an upgrade. The improved XC90 has a more contemporary style, a more elegant interior, and advanced safety features including a 360-degree surround view camera, pedestrian and cyclist detection. Volvo also promises an R-Design option with a “unique grille, larger wheels, mirror covers in matte silver, and sportier Sport Contour seats.” William Griffith 2016 Toyota Prius (pictured: 2014 Toyota Prius): Toyota has yet to officially unveil the 2016 Toyota Prius. But CR reports the redesigned hybrid vehicle icon will still be a 5-door hatchback but will feature a new platform and deliver a longer range from a small gas engine and an electric motor. A lithium-ion battery upgrade may offer even more range. Toyota officially unveiled the 2016 Toyota Prius on September 8. The redesigned hybrid vehicle icon will still be a 5-door hatchback but will feature a new platform and deliver a longer range from a small gas engine and an electric motor. An improved battery promies to deliver a 10 percent improvement on fuel efficiency. John Locher / AP Photo 2016 Tesla Model X. Tesla is currently taking reservations for its Model X, which features “falcon wing” doors that appear to pay homage to the Delorean. The Model X is an all-electric SUV, a follow up to its highly successful Model S sedan, which forced Consumer Reports to revise its grading system. CR reports there will be 70-, 85-, and 90- kWh battery packs available, with the 85-kWh delivering a range of about 200 miles. Tesla 2016 Chevrolet Camaro. According to General Motors, the sixth-generation Camaro will deliver a “more nimble driving experience” thanks to a lighter design that sheds around 200 pounds and a wide range of powertrains. It has also been given a more “athletic” look and aerodynamically optimized with a “driver-focused” interior with enhanced technology. GM claims the only thing the newest Camaro has in common with previous versions is the “rear bowtie emblem and the SS badge.” Rebecca Cook / Reuters 2016 Toyota Mirai. According to Kelley Blue Book, “mirai” means “future” in Japanese. The Mirai is a four-door midsize sedan that runs on hydrogen and apparently has a range of 300 miles. KBB reports the Mirai can go from zero to 60 in about nine seconds and its fuel cell technology delivers 153 horsepower. Since it runs on hydrogen, it’s a very quiet ride and refilling the tank can take a few minutes, compared to recharging an electric vehicle which can take considerably longer. Courtesy of Toyota 2016 BMW X1. The newest version of the X1 shares a front-drive platform with its cousin, the MINI Cooper hatchback. CR reports only a 2.0-liter, 228 horsepower turbo engine will be available at the X1’s initial launch later this fall. All-wheel drive and front-wheel drive options will be available. Courtesy of BMW Group 2016 Mazda CX-3. This Mazda is a compact crossover with an exterior that KBB says “reflects the sharpest and most dynamic take on the KODO look to date.” KODO – Soul of Motion is Mazda’s design philosophy, which aims to capture the spirit of movement even while the vehicle is at rest. The CX-3 has all-wheel drive and its interior has a modern-looking cabin. Mazda 2016 Hyundai Tucson. The redesigned Hyundai Tucson has been given a style that makes it a little more like its sibling, the Hyundai Santa Fe. The new design includes a hexagonal grille, LED headlights, and high wheel arches to create the illusion of motion. The Tucson is built on a new platform that gives it a roomy interior and 18.5 cubic feet of cargo space (when the second row is up). Hyundai 2016 Nissan Titan. KBB says Nissan is making “significant changes” to the Titan after a long wait that are meant to address consumer complaints about a lack of variety. Nissan is making two versions of the pickup available, the Titan and the Titan XD (pictured). The XD features a larger frame than its counterpart capable of towing 10,000 to 12,000 pounds. It is also available with a diesel V8 engine. Nissan Now, the Model S and Model X can also parallel park for you, and alert you with a series of beeps and flashing messages if you zone out or fall asleep. Less exciting changes that came with the update affect the visual display inside the cars, including new instrument panels, larger app windows, and a new clock.
It’s important to note that the software update won’t work everywhere; it’s mainly geared toward highway driving, and isn’t prepared to handle obstacles like construction, cyclists, stop signs, and traffic lights – so don’t try it out in your neighborhood. And Tesla owners with models prior to 2014 are out of luck: there’s no way to retrofit the hardware to get your car to be semi-autonomous.
Elon Musk told Wired he thinks Tesla drivers will see the Autopilot update as a “profound experience” that will only get better. In the next three years – regulatory-approval depending – Musk said his cars will be fully autonomous, putting Teslas ahead of other carmakers with 2020 deadlines .
